document.masterDocTitle: Archaeococcoid scale insects (Hemiptera: Coccoidea) from the tropical high mountains of the Andean Cordillera, South America

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Archaeococcoid scale insects (Hemiptera: Coccoidea) from the tropical high mountains of the Andean Cordillera, South America

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remark .
Unruh & Gullan ( 2008 b)
designated a lectotype for this species, provided diagnoses of the adult female and first-instar nymph, with a complete list of type material and a key to distinguish the adult female from all other species of the genus. Their diagnosis of the first-instar nymphs of
C. abrahami
was adapted from the original description because they did not have access to specimens of this instar. I recorded firstinstar nymphs associated with adult females and thus provide the first detailed description and illustration of the first-instar nymphs and adult females of this species. Recently,
Kondo & Unruh ( 2009 )
published a photograph of live adult females of
C. abrahami
and included this species in their key to South American species of Iceryini.

ADULT FEMALE
(
Fig. 2
)

Description based on
8 females
in fair condition.

Material examined. GUYANA
: Syntypes females, 4 slides of
Crypticerya abrahami Newstead, Issororo, N.W. Dist.
British Guiana (= Guyana ),
3 .vi. 15
. Syntypes examined during a visit, 1986 , to BMNH .

VENEZUELA
: near Merida, 2000 m , on
Calliandra falcata Benth.
( Fabaceae ), November 2, 1984 , I. Foldi coll.,
4 adult
females on 4 slides, and 5 first-instar nymphs on 1 slide. MNHN .

Mounted material : Body broadly oval, 5.6‚Äì5.9 mm long, 5.0‚Äì 5.2 mm wide; rounded at both ends. A good diagnostic feature for the adult female of this species is the presence of the long collared setae in a broad band around entire ventral submargin.

Dorsum . Derm rather thickened. Multilocular pores of 4 types : (i) each 9‚Äì10 ¬µm in diameter, with a large triangular centre (
Fig. 2
F) with 3 large inner loculi plus 3 pairs of outer loculi, evenly scattered across all body segments; (ii) larger pores, each 11‚Äì12 ¬µm in diameter, with a large quadrilocular centre (
Fig. 2
D) with 4 inner loculi plus 12 outer small loculi, densely scattered throughout; (iii) smaller pores (
Fig. 2
A), each 8‚Äì9 ¬µm in diameter, with 2 large inner loculi and a tiny subcentral loculus, plus 4 elongate outer loculi, present on head and thorax, and (iv) medium-sized pores (
Fig. 2
K), each 8‚Äì10 ¬µm wide, with a strongly sclerotised opening centre plus 8‚Äì12 outer loculi, abundant around anal opening. Hair-like setae (
Fig. 2
E), each 45‚Äì80 ¬µm long densely distributed throughout all body segments. Slender flagellate setae (
Fig. 2
S) scattered throughout. Spiniform setae absent. Anal opening dorsal, 95 ¬µm wide, surrounded by hair-like setae and pores; anal tube (
Fig. 2
G), simple, about 130 ¬µm long with a sclerotised inner end.

Venter . Multilocular pores mainly circular to slightly oval in shape, of 5 types : (i) circular pores, each with an oval centre (
Fig. 2
R) with 2 central loculi plus a tiny central opening of a small ductule plus 12 outer loculi, scattered, but particularly abundant in vulvar region; (ii) similar pores but with a triangular centre with 3 inner loculi plus 9‚Äì12 outer loculi, rarer, scattered; (iii) medium sized pores same as on dorsum (
Fig. 2
K), each 8‚Äì10 ¬µm in diameter, with a large circular centre plus 10 large outer loculi, scattered over entire surface; (iv) broadly oval pores (
Fig. 2
L, O ), each 11‚Äì13 ¬µm wide, with a large bilocular centre plus 7 outer loculi, sparsely scattered on abdomen, and in groups of peristigmatic pores around each thoracic spiracle, associated with pore with Y-shaped opening and with irregular rim (
Fig. 2
P); and (v) pores 12‚Äì13 ¬µm in diameter, each with 4 large loculi centre plus 12‚Äì14 outer loculi (
Fig. 2
D) (similar to those on dorsum), rare on head and thorax. Long collared setae (
Fig. 2
J), each 450‚Äì650 ¬µm in a broad band around entire ventral submargin; intermixed with (a) shorter and scarcer hair-like setae, each 65‚Äì140 ¬µm long, plus (b) longer setae, each 200‚Äì 300 ¬µm long; also with multilocular pores, 9‚Äì10 ¬µm in diameter, with bilocular or round centre ( types (i) and (v) above). Hair-like setae (
Fig. 2
E), each 45‚Äì80 ¬µm long, similar of those of dorsum, densely scattered over entire surface. Clusters of setae and pores absent around margin. Flagellate setae (
Fig. 2
S) similar to those of dorsum scattered throughout venter.

Antennae 11 segmented
Fig. 2
B), 800‚Äì850 ¬µm long; each antennal segment elongate with long flagellate setae and a few fleshy setae; apical segment longest, 110 ¬µm long, 60 ¬µm wide, with 2 or 3 long flagellate setae, each 290‚Äì330 ¬µm, plus about 8‚Äì10 hair-like setae, each 120‚Äì150 ¬µm long, and 2 or 3 straight fleshy setae, each 40‚Äì60 ¬µm long. Eyes circular at base of antennae. Small convex pores (
Fig. 2
C) and minute setae (organ sensoria) on derm near scape and eyespots. Labium 3 segmented, apical segment with numerous hairlike setae anteriorly, each 70‚Äì100 ¬µm long, and about 4‚Äì6 spatulate setae on apex.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2. Adult female of
Crypticerya abrahami (Newstead)
. Where: A = pore with 2 large central loculi and 4 small elongated outer loculi; B = antenna; C = small convex pores and minute setae at base of scape; D = multilocular pore with 4 large central loculi and 12 small outer loculi; E = hair-like setae; F = pore with 3 large central loculi and 6 small outer loculi; G = anal tube; H = cicatrix; I = abdominal spiracle; J = long collared seta on submargin; K = multilocular pore around anal area; L = broadly oval multilocular pore; M = metathoracic leg; N = campaniform sensillum on trochanter; O = thoracic spiracle with enlargement of perispiracular pore (pp); P = pore with Y-shaped opening and an irregular rim. R = multilocular pores with a central ductule around vulvar opening; S = flagellate seta; T = hair.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Thoracic spiracles (
Fig. 2
O ) unequal in size, with elongate peritremes; posterior pair larger, 130 ¬µm wide, anterior pair 90 ¬µm wide; each atrium without pores but with a large group of perispiracular multilocular pores (
Fig. 2
O ); each spiracle with a straight apodeme about 200 ¬µm long. Abdominal spiracles (
Fig.
2
I): 3 pairs located on posterior three abdominal segments (VI‚ÄìVIII) with peritreme about 22 ¬µm wide; atrium without pores.

Legs well developed (
Fig. 2
M), prothoracic legs shorter than meso- and metathoracic legs. Metathoracic legs: coxa about 300 ¬µm long, 120 ¬µm wide, with a large apodeme and with a strong articulatory sclerosis; trochanter + femur 480 ¬µm long; trochanter with 3 campaniform sensillum (
Fig. 2
N) on each face, plus about 5 or 6 setae, each 40‚Äì60 ¬µm long, and one ventral trochanteral seta 250 ¬µm long; femur robust, nearly as wide ( 230 ¬µm) as long ( 250 ¬µm), with few setae dorsally and laterally, each 60‚Äì70 ¬µm long, plus one long seta ventrally, 140 ¬µm long; tibia 400 ¬µm long, 80 ¬µm, wide articulating strongly with femur, with about 18 setae along ventral margin, each 50‚Äì70 ¬µm long, stouter towards apex, plus a few setae dorsally; tarsus 200 ¬µm long, 70 ¬µm wide, with tarsal setae increasing in length toward apex up to 60 ¬µm; claw 60 ¬µm long, without a denticle, but with one pair of acute digitules, each 50 ¬µm long. Ovisac pore band and marsupial pore band absent. Cicatrices (
Fig. 2
H): 3 , grouped in a semicircle posteromedially to vulva; each rather elliptical, 140‚Äì 160 ¬µm long, with a mosaic surface. Vulvar opening a transverse fissure, on ventromedial area of abdomen, about 700 ¬µm wide, surrounded by multilocular pores (
Fig. 2
R), each 10‚Äì12 ¬µm in diameter, and each with a mostly bilocular centre surrounding a minute, elongate central loculus and 10‚Äì14 outer loculi ( type (i) above).

Description based on
2 specimens
in good condition.
Mounted material. Body oval, elongate 850‚Äì1000 ¬µm long, 450‚Äì550 ¬µm wide.

Dorsum . Multilocular pores of 2 types : (i) hexagonal pores (
Fig. 3
C) 7‚Äì8 ¬µm wide, each with a large bilocular centre plus 6 smaller outer loculi, and (ii) circular pores (
Fig. 3
G), each 9‚Äì10 ¬µm in diameter, with a round centre plus 8 outer loculi; both pore types present in transverse rows over entire surface of body. Hairlike setae (Fig, 3 K), each 30‚Äì80 ¬µm long, scattered on head and thorax, and in transverse rows on abdominal segments.

Venter . Small multilocular pores (
Fig. 3
H), each about 6‚Äì7 ¬µm in diameter, with 2 large inner loculi plus 2‚Äì4 smaller outer loculi, present submarginally and submedially on abdominal segments III‚ÄìVII. Larger multilocular pores (
Fig. 3
G), each 9‚Äì10 ¬µm in diameter, with a round centre and 8 outer loculi, similar to type (ii) on dorsum, rare; also quadrilocular pores (
Fig. 3
H) present in submarginal and submedian areas. Setal distribution: collared setae (
Fig. 3
L) present marginally around body, each about 450‚Äì650 ¬µm long, with large, conical collars, setal length increasing towards abdominal apex (
Fig. 3
L); these marginal setae forming segmental clusters of 2 or 3 setae: one long collared seta plus 1 or 2 shorter hair-like setae, each 100‚Äì200 ¬µm long (
Fig. 3
O ). Hair-like setae, each 40‚Äì70 ¬µm long, in a transverse row 1 seta wide on abdominal segments III‚ÄìVI. Anal tube (
Fig. 3
D) 30 ¬µm wide, with an inner sclerotized ring of polygonal wax pores (
Fig. 3
F), plus 6‚Äì8 multilocular pores. each pore (
Fig. 3
E) with 1 circular central loculus plus 6 similar outer loculi. Anal opening sclerotised. Posterior end of abdomen with 3 pairs of long caudal setae (
Fig. 3
J), each 1.0‚Äì 1.2 mm long; these caudal setae surround a median pair of shorter collared setae, length about 600 ¬µm, similar to collared setae around of body margin.

Antennae 6 segmented (
Fig. 3
M), 420 ¬µm long; scape with 2 or 3 setae, each 40‚Äì50 ¬µm; segments II‚ÄìV with a few long setae, each 80‚Äì160 ¬µm long; apical segment 150 ¬µm long, more than 1 / 3 rd total length of antenna, with numerous long hair-like setae, each about 200‚Äì400 ¬µm long, plus about 13‚Äì16 shorter setae varying in length between 90 to 160 ¬µm, and a few fleshy setae, each 35‚Äì40 ¬µm long. Eyespots conical (
Fig. 3
N), located near antennal bases. Sensory pores present in a small group of 2 or 3 , between antennae and eyes, each 5‚Äì7 ¬µm in diameter. Labium with 12‚Äì16 hair-like setae, plus some spatulate setae at apex. Thoracic spiracles (
Fig. 3
B), each with an elongate peritreme 25 and 40 ¬µm wide respectively; pores absent from atrium. Abdominal spiracles in 3 pairs, each very small, about 3‚Äì4 ¬µm wide, without pores in atrium. A single cicatrice present posteroventrally. Prothoracic leg (
Fig. 3
A) lengths: coxa 80 ¬µm long, with 2 or 3 setae, each 40‚Äì60 ¬µm long; trochanter + femur 210 ¬µm long; trochanter with 2 campaniform sensilla on each face, with few setae plus a 1 long trochanteral seta, 110‚Äì130 ¬µm; femur with few setae, each 30‚Äì60 ¬µm long; tibia 230 ¬µm long with few setae, each 30‚Äì50 ¬µm long; tarsus 140 ¬µm long, with 3 or 4 setae, each 20‚Äì40 ¬µm long; tarsal digitules each about 50 ¬µm long; claw 35 ¬µm long, with a pair of digitules apparently of unequal length, each 45‚Äì90 ¬µm long; claw without a denticle.
Distribution. Colombia , Guyana , Venezuela .

Remarks. Three species,
C. abrahami (Newstead)
,
C. pimentae (Newstead)
and
C. rosae (Riley & Howard)
, belong in the
Crypticerya rosae
group of
Unruh & Gullan ( 2008 b)
, who considered these species to be morphologically identical. Unruh & Gullan did not synonymise them because they differ genetically and are found in different regions:
C. abrahami
in Colombia , Guyana and Venezuela ,
C. pimentae
in Jamaica and
C. rosae
in Florida ( USA ) and Mexico .

Crypticerya abrahami (Newstead)
is rather similar to
C. rosae (Riley & Howard)
in that both females form neither an ovisac nor a marsupium and the secretion on the dorsal surface forms only a fine, thin coat; they also share broadly oval mutilocular pores with a bilocular centre, circular pores with a trilocular centre; multilocular pores with a bilocular centre with a central ductule; also the length of the marginal-submarginal hair-like setae is nearly the same ( 650 ¬µm and 625 ¬µm long). However,
C. abrahami
differs from
C. rosae
as follows: in the presence of pores with Y-shaped opening; in having multilocular pores with a circular centre and 10 outer loculi on anal area, and in the presence of numerous perispiracular thoracic pores.

In first-instar nymphs of
C. abrahami ,
Newstead ( 1917 )
indicated 4 pairs of caudal setae, but in reality there are only 3 pairs (each 1.0‚Äì 1.2 mm long); the apparent median pair are much shorter and correspond to collared setae, of length about 600 ¬µm, which is the same length as collared setae on the margin of the body. First-instar nymphs of
C. rosae
and
C. multicicatrices
also have 3 pairs of caudal setae, with maximum length of perhaps 1270 ¬µm and 1100 ¬µm, respectively. First-instar nymphs of
C. abrahami
differ from those of
C. rosae
in the presence of dorsal hexagonal pores and ventral quadrilocular pores. Also long marginal collared setae are distributed along the entire margin in
C. abrahami
, but only on the abdominal segments in
C. rosae
.
